metadata.title: Degradation of 1,4-Dioxane by Biochar Supported Nano Magnetite Particles Activating Persulfate

sections.text:

Degradation of 1,4-Dioxane by Biochar Supported Nano Magnetite Particles Activating Persulfate Da Ouyang, Jingchun Yan, Linbo Qian, Yun Chen, Lu Han, Anqi Su, Wenying Zhang, Hao Ni, Mengfang Chen

The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Degradation of 1,4-Dioxane by Biochar Supported Nano Magnetite Particles 1 Activating Persulfate 2 3 Da Ouyang a,b, Jingchun Yan a, Linbo Qian a, Yun Chen a,b, Lu Han a, Anqi Su a,b, 4 Wenying Zhang a,b, Hao Ni a, Mengfang Chen a,* 5
6 a Key Laboratory of Soil Environment and Pollution Remediation, Institute of Soil 7 Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing 210008, China. 8 b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China. 9
10 * Corresponding author 11 Tel.: +86-25-86881847; fax: +86-25-86881126. 12 E-mail address: mfchen@issas.ac.cn (Menfang Chen). 13

2
ABSTRACT 15 Nano magnetite biochar composite (nFe3O4/biochar) was synthesized and used to 16 activate persulfate for the degradation of 1,4-dioxane. Analytical techniques using 17 X-ray diffraction (XRD), fourier transform infrared analysis (FTIR), X-ray 18 photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) indicated 19 that nFe3O4 was spherical and successfully loaded onto the surface of biochar. The 20 results of batch-scale experiments illustrated that the 1,4-dioxane degradation 21 efficiency in aqueous phase was 98.0% after 120 min reaction with the composite 22 mass ratio of 1:1 between nFe3O4 and the pine needle biochar pyrolyzed at 400 oC 23 (P400) under the initial neutral pH. An electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) study, 24 free radical quenching experiment and XPS analysis were undertaken to illustrate the 25 mechanism of persulfate activation by nFe3O4/biochar. Under acidic and neutral 26
conditions, the predominant free radical was SO4 •- whereas •OH and SO4 •- 27 predominated when the initial pH was 9.0. The XPS analysis indicated that Fe(II) and 28 oxygenated functional groups activated persulfate. In addition, carbon-carbon double 29 bonds would be transformed into ketone and quinone which could activate persulfate 30 during the reaction. 31 Key Words: Nano magnetite; Pine needle; Biochar; Persulfate; 1,4-Dioxane; 32 Activation 33
34

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 35
sections.text:
1,4-dioxane is classified as a potential B2 carcinogen by the Environmental 36 Protection Agency of the United States (Eberle et al., 2016) and has been frequently 37 detected in groundwater and surface waters (Barndõk et al., 2014) because of its 38 widespread utilization in industrial activities (And and Hua, 2000; Isaacson et al., 39 2006). It was mainly used as a stabilizing agent for chlorinated hydrocarbons and 40 existed as a by-product in many cosmetics (Abe, 1999; Sekar and Dichristina, 2014). 41 Since 1,4-dioxane is completely aqueous soluble and semi-volatile, it is quite mobile 42 in the groundwater and surface water environment. Available remediation 43 technologies for 1,4-dioxane such as air stripping, carbon adsorption are limited by its 44 solubility, boiling point and vapor pressure. In addition, biodegradation tends to be 45 ineffective due to its heterocyclic structure (Long et al., 2014). Advanced oxidation 46 processes (AOPs) offer a promising alternative to remediate 1,4-dioxane 47 contaminated soil and groundwater. Using peroxone activated persulfate, Eberle et al. 48 (2016) successfully achieved co-degradation of 1,4-dioxane and chlorinated solvents. 49 Li et al. (2016) identified that several molecular organic acids, hydroxyaldehyde and 50 1,2-ethanediol diformate were degradation products of 1,4-dioxane during the 51 sono-activated persulfate processes. On account of its high efficiency for the removal 52 of 1,4-dioxane in soil and water, AOP based on persulfate has attracted much attention 53 in recent years (Sekar and Dichristina, 2014). 54 Transitional metals such as Fe2+, Co2+ and Ag+ can activate persulfate to generate 55 SO4 •- (Teel et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2012) and Fe2+ is one of the most effective reagents 56
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
4
for persulfate activation by equation (1) (Woods et al., 1963; Zhu et al., 2016): 57
Fe2+ + S2O8 2- → SO4 •- + Fe3+ + SO4 2- (1) 58 However, previous studies found that Fe2+ could also react with SO4 •- by 59 equation (2), resulting in rapid scavenging of SO4 •- and lowering the efficiency of 60 trichloroethylene degradation by persulfate (Liang et al., 2004a). 61
Fe2+ + SO4 •- → Fe3+ + SO4 2- (2) 62 To reduce the competition of SO4 •-, successful attempts were made by adding 63 chelators such as ethylenediaminetetraacetic and citric acids into the system of 64 Fe2+-persulfate (Liang et al., 2004b). Nano-magnetite particles (nFe3O4) were also 65 introduced as Fe2+ alternative to activate persulfate for the degradation of 66 sulfamonomethoxine (Yan et al., 2011). However, with high surface energy and 67 magnetic interaction, nFe3O4 tends to aggregate, therefore lowering its efficacy for 68 persulfate activation. Recently, nano-materials being loaded onto carbon materials 69 were investigated to improve the activation efficacy. Zhang et al. (2016) found that 70 nanoscale magnetic CuFe2O4/Multi-Walled Carbon Nanotubes (MWCNTS) achieved 71 the optimal performance of the persulfate activation with a mass ratio of 2:1 between 72 CuFe2O4 and MWCNTS on the degradation of diethyl phthalate. It was also reported 73 that by dispersing nFe3O4 onto graphene oxides, the trichloroethylene degradation 74 efficiency of nFe3O4 activating persulfate system had been increased significantly 75 (Yan et al., 2016). 76 Produced from biomass under low oxygen condition, biochar is a promising 77 environmental remediation material because of low cost, large specific surface area 78
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
5
and strong adsorption capacity. Biochar possesses a variety of oxygen-containing 79 functional groups such as carboxyl, hydroxyl and carbonyl, which can activate 80 pesulfate to generate SO4 •- (Liang et al., 2009; Duan et al., 2015). In addition, biochar 81 can be successfully employed to disperse and stabilize nanoparticles to enhance their 82 potential in environmental applications (Yan et al., 2014; Han et al., 2015). 83 In this study, biochar supported nano magnetite particles (nFe3O4/biochar) were 84 synthesized via a reverse co-precipitation method (Yan et al., 2011) and examined as 85 an efficient persulfate activator for 1,4-dioxane degradation. The objectives of this 86 study were to (1) synthesize and characterize a novel nFe3O4/biochar; (2) evaluate the 87 1,4-dioxane degradation potency and controlling factors of nFe3O4/biochar-persulfate 88 system and (3) explore the activation mechanism of persulfate by nFe3O4/biochar. 89 90 2. Materials and methods 91 2.1. Materials 92 Ferrous sulfate (FeSO4·7H2O) and sodium persulfate (Na2S2O8, > 98.0%) were 93 purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Suzhou, China). Iron nitrate 94 nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, > 98.5%) was obtained from Kelong Chemical 95 Company (Chendu, China). 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrrolidine N-oxide (DMPO, 97%) was 96 purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Shanghai, China). Dichloromethane (chromatography 97 grade) was gained from Tedia Company Inc (Shanghai, China). 1,4-dioxane ( > 99.9%) 98 was acquired from Aladdin Industrial Corporation (Shanghai, China). All of these 99
chemicals were of analytical grade. Ultrapure water with a resistivity of 18.25 MΩ 100
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
6
was used for preparing aqueous solutions. 101 2.2. Preparation of nFe3O4/biochar composite 102 Pinus massoniana pine needles were collected from a hill in Nanjing 103 (118°48'25.13''E, 32o3'34.5''N), China. After being washed by ultrapure water several 104 times, pine needles were dried at 80 oC to a constant weight and grinded by a cutting 105 mill and passed through a 100-mesh sieve. Then, the pine needle was pyrolyzed in a 106 muffle furnace under the oxygen-limited condition. The starting temperature was 100 107 oC and held for 2 h. Then, temperature was increased to 300 oC, 400 oC, 500 oC and 108 700 oC, respectively, at a rate of 10 oC min-1 and maintained for 2 h (Fang et al., 2014; 109 Fang et al., 2015a). Biochar samples were hereafter referred to as P300, P400, P500 110 and P700 with numbers referring to pyrolyzing temperatures. 111 The synthesis procedure of nFe3O4/biochar was described as follows: 0.60 g 112 biochar was dispersed into 3.0 mM NH3·H2O with a total volume of 50 mL, then 113 placed in an ultrasound bath (45 Hz, 100 W) at 65 oC. 1.39 g FeSO4·7H2O and 1.01 g 114 Fe(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 20 mL ultrapure water and gradually added into the 115 above solution (Yan et al., 2016). After 60 min reaction, the solution was cooled down 116 to a room temperature and the precipitated nFe3O4/biochar was magnetically 117 separated and washed with ultrapure water until neutral pH was achieved. The mass 118 ratio between nFe3O4 and biochar of the prepared composite was 1:1 and 119 nFe3O4/biochar with different mass ratios was also prepared by changing the mass of 120 biochar dispersed in the solution. 121 2.3. Experimental procedures 122
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
7
Sacrificial batch experiments were conducted in a rotary shaker with 150 rpm at 123 temperature 25 oC in 22 mL glass bottles containing 20 mL reaction solution. The 124 initial pH of the reaction solution was adjusted to 7.0 by adding 0.1 M HCl or NaOH. 125 Briefly, 20.0 µM 1,4-dioxane and 1.0 g L-1 nFe3O4 or desired amounts of 126 nFe3O4/biochar with different mass ratios (the content of total iron concentration was 127 kept the same with 1.0 g L-1 nFe3O4) were added into glass vials. Then 1.0 mL 0.16 M 128 persulfate was added into the reaction solution and the glass vials were capped tightly. 129 Control experiments were also carried out under the same conditions with neither 130 activators nor persulfate being added. Periodically, 4.0 mL solution was sampled from 131 the vials and the reaction was immediately quenched with 1.0 mL anhydrous ethanol. 132 Then, 8.0 mL dichloromethane solution was utilized to extract the remaining 133 1,4-dioxane. Dichloromethane phase was analyzed by a Gas Chromatograph-Mass 134 Spectrometer. All the batch experiments were undertaken in triplicate, and mean 135 values were reported. 136 2.4. Analytical methods 137 The concentration of 1,4-dioxane was determined by an Gas Chromatograph- 138 Mass Spectrometer (Agilent, 7890A-5975C, USA) with a HP-5 chromatographic 139 column. The concentration of Fe2+ and Fe3+ were measured using 1,10-phenanthroline 140 monohydrate with ultraviolet Spectrometer (Unico UV-2000, USA). Free radicals’ 141 electron paramagnetic resonance spectra were obtained on an electron paramagnetic 142 resonance (EPR) spectrometer (Bruker EMX-10/12, Germany), with a resonance 143 frequency of 9.85 GHz, microwave power of 20.0 mW, modulation frequency of 100 144
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
8
kHz, modulation amplitude of 1.0 G, sweep width of 200 G, time constant of 40.96 145 ms, sweep time of 81.92 s, and receiver gain of 1.0×103. Morphology of 146 nFe3O4/biochar was examined by scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Hitachi, 147 S-3400N II, Japan). nFe3O4 and nFe3O4/biochar crystal were analyzed by X-ray 148 diffraction (XRD) pattern on a diffractometer with Cu KR radiation (Rigaku Ultima 149 IV, Japan). The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were analyzed by X-ray 150 photoelectron spectroscopy (Simadzu AXIS UltraDL, Japan). FTIR (Nicolet iS10, 151 Thermo scientific, USA) was employed to determine surface functional groups. 152
153 3. Results and discussion 154 3.1. Characterization of nFe3O4/biochar composite 155 The morphology of nFe3O4/biochar was obtained by SEM. As illustrated in Fig. 156 1, the pine needle biochar was flaky with the development of many micro-pores (Fig. 157 1a), whereas nFe3O4 particles were spherical (Fig. 1b). As for nFe3O4/biochar, nFe3O4 158 was homogeneously dispersed onto the biochar surface without apparent aggregation 159 (Fig. 1c). XRD spectrum was also utilized to explore the phase structures of nFe3O4 160 and nFe3O4/biochar. As revealed in Fig. 1d, nFe3O4 diffraction peaks with 2 theta 161 values of 30.2°, 35.5°, 43.2° and 57.2° were observed. These peaks were 162 corresponded to typical nFe3O4 diffractions of (220), (311), (400), (422) and (511), 163 respectively (Yan et al., 2016). XRD peak at 2 theta = 20 ~ 25° was assigned to the 164 amorphous structure of graphite of biochar (Han et al., 2015). Both characteristic 165 diffraction peaks of nFe3O4 and biochar in the XRD spectrum of nFe3O4/biochar 166
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
9
implied successful synthesis of the composites. 167 The FTIR spectra of biochar prepared under different pyrolysis temperatures 168 were shown in Fig. 1e. As observed from FTIR spectra, the bands at 3230 cm-1 and 169 3423 cm-1 were assigned to the stretching vibration of hydroxyl groups. After heating 170 to 400 oC, the band intensities at 2923 cm-1 (asymmetric stretching for aliphatic 171 functional groups) and 2852 cm-1 (symmetric stretching for aliphatic functional 172 groups) gradually disappeared due to removal of low boiling point components (Zhu 173 et al., 2014). The band at 1616 cm-1 assigned to C=C and C=O stretching slightly 174 increased from P300 to P400 and gradually decreased from P500 to P700 (Chen et al., 175 2008; Fang et al., 2015b). The symmetric C-O stretching (1035 and 1120 cm-1) for the 176 source material of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin was decreased from P300 to 177 P400 (Uchimiya et al., 2011). The C-H bending for aromatic out of plane deformation 178 (873 cm-1) become apparent for P500 and P700. As shown above, the increase of 179 pyrolysis temperature leads to the loss of oxygen functional groups and the growth of 180 aromatic structures (Tilly, 2003). Comparing with P300, P400, P500 and P700, the 181 bending for vibrations of Fe2+-O2- (585 cm-1) and Fe3+-O2- (445 cm-1) appeared in 182 nFe3O4/biochar (Ahmad et al., 2009), indicating of nFe3O4 being successfully loaded 183 onto biochar. 184 Figure 1f presented the wide survey XPS spectra of nFe3O4/biochar. The peak of 185 O(1s) at 531.5 eV may represent the generation of Fe-O-C because the peak of Fe-O 186 at 530.3 eV would be shifted to higher binding energy about 1-3 eV with the 187 formation of metal-O-C bonds (Zhou et al., 2011), indicating the formation of 188
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
10
chemical bonds between biochar and nFe3O4. 189 3.2. 1,4-Dioxane degradation by persulfate activated by nFe3O4/biochar 190 3.2.1. Effects of biochar pyrolysis temperatures on the 1,4-dioxane degradation 191 1,4-Dioxane adsorption onto biochar and nFe3O4/biochar were tested before 192 investigating 1,4-dioxane degradation within nFe3O4 and nFe3O4/biochar-persulfate 193 system and the removal of 1,4-dioxane by adsorption was negligible and this because 194 1,4-dioxane is completely soluble. The influence of biochar pyrolysis temperature on 195 nFe3O4/biochar composites activation efficacy towards persulfate is shown in Fig. 2a. 196 Degradation efficiency of 1,4-dioxane by nFe3O4/biochar (P300, P400, P500, P700) 197 activating persulfate were 95.0%, 97.9%, 87.0%, 39.2%, respectively, which was in 198 accordance with the content of functional group in biochar. Functional groups in 199 biochars such as carboxyl and quinone have been shown to activate persulfate. (Liang 200 et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2011; Fang et al., 2013; Duan et al., 2015). 201
BCsurface-OOH + S2O8 2- → SO4 •- + BCsurface-OO •- + HSO4 - (3) 202
BCsurface-OH + S2O8 2- → SO4 •- + BCsurface-O •- + HSO4 - (4) 203 Quinones + H2O → 2Semiquinone •- + 2H+ (5) 204
Semiquinone•- + S2O8 2- → SO4 •- + Quinones (6) 205 From the FTIR analysis, the band at 1616 cm-1 assigned to C=C and C=O 206 stretching slightly increased from P300 to P400 and gradually decreased from P500 to 207 P700, which were in accordance with the 1,4-dioxane degradation experimental 208 results (Fig. 2a). It was further reported that, comparing to P300, P500 and P700, the 209 optimized persulfate activation was achieved for P400 because it was rich in 210
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
11
oxygen-centered and persistent free radicals which were more active in the persulfate 211 activation (Fang et al., 2015a). Therefore, nFe3O4/P400 had the best performance in 212 the experiment and was selected for further study. 213 3.2.2. Effect of mass ratios of nFe3O4/biochar on 1,4-dioxane degradation 214 The effects of different mass ratios of nFe3O4/P400 (2:1, 1:1, 1:3, and 1:5) on 215 1,4-dioxane degradation were illustrated in Fig. 2b. A 1,4-dioxane removal efficiency 216 of 85.0% was achieved for nFe3O4 (1.0 g L -1) and sodium persulfate (8.0 mM), 217 whereas nFe3O4/P400 (2:1, 1:1, 1:3, 1:5) and persulfate within the 120 min reaction 218 time removed 89.2%, 98.6%, 77.4% and 39.5% of the 1,4-dioxane respectively. From 219 the results, when the mass ratios between biochar and nFe3O4 were smaller than 1:1, 220 the 1,4-dioxane degradation efficiency improved with increasing mass ratio. When the 221 mass ratios between biochar and nFe3O4 were greater than 1:1, the 1,4-dioxane 222 degradation efficiency declined with increasing mass ratio. High accessibility of 223 reactants towards the active sites (≡Fe2+/≡Fe3+) could be facilitated by the 224 enhancement of surface area and pore volume when the ratios between biochar and 225 nFe3O4 were smaller (Zubir et al., 2014). However, an excessive loading of biochar 226 would block the active sites of nFe3O4/biochar leading to the reduction in efficiencies 227 (Yan et al., 2014). It was illustrated from the experiments that a mass ratio of 228 nFe3O4/biochar at 1:1 shows the best performance in the degradation of 1,4-dioxane. 229 Therefore, nFe3O4/biochar with a mass ratio of 1:1 was selected for further study. 230 3.2.3. The influence of initial pH on the 1,4-dioxane degradation 231 The initial pH of the reaction solution was another important factor influencing 232
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
12
on 1,4-dioxane degradation efficiency. Fig. 2c illustrated the influence of the initial 233 pH on the degradation of 1,4-dioxane with nFe3O4/P400 (a mass ratio of 1:1) and 8.0 234 mM persulfate. The obtained data indicated that comparing with Fe2+, nFe3O4/P400 235 had relatively high activation efficacy in persulfate under a wide range of initial pH 236 (from 3.0 to 9.0). After 120 min reaction, the removal efficiency of 1,4-dioxane were 237 97.2%, 94.5%, 83.6% under the initial pH of 3.0, 7.0 and 9.0, respectively. The 238 findings were largely consistent with the previously studies (Yan et al., 2011; Zhang et 239 al., 2016). When the initial pH was set at 11.0, the removal efficiency of 1,4-dioxane 240 sharply declined to 4.6%, which was attributable to the depletion of SO4 •- and •OH by 241 reacting with OH-. The data could be explained by equations (7), (8), (9) and (10) 242 (Lau et al., 2007). 243
SO4 •- + H2O → HSO4 - + •OH (7) 244
SO4 •- + OH- → SO4 2- + •OH (8) 245 •OH + •OH→ H2O2 (9) 246
S2O8 2- + H2O2 → 2H + + 2 SO4 2- + O2 (10) 247 3.2.4 Effects of persulfate concentration on 1,4-dioxane degradation 248 The concentration of persulfate is another important factor affecting the 249 1,4-dioxane removal efficiency (Long et al., 2014; Eberle et al., 2016). As shown in 250 Fig. 2d, the 1,4-dioxane concentrations after reaction was 7.2, 3.0, 0.43, and 0.46 µM 251 and the degradation efficiency was 63.5%, 84.6%, 97.8% and 97.6% corresponding to 252 the concentrations of persulfate at 2.0, 4.0, 8.0 and 16.0 mM, respectively. The data 253 indicated that the 1,4-dioxane degradation efficiency increased in direct proportion to 254
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
13
the persulfate concentration. However, when the concentration of persulfate increased 255 to 32.0 mM, the concentration remaining in solution was 1.36 µM and the degradation 256 efficiency dropped slightly to 93.1%. At high persulfate concentrations, the SO4 •- 257 generated from nFe3O4/biochar-persulfate system increased and excessive persulfate 258
reacts with SO4 •- to form S2O8 •-(equation (11) and (12)) itself, resulting in the decrease 259 in 1,4-dioxane degradation (Liang et al., 2004a; Yu et al., 2004; Liang and Lee, 2008; 260 Yan et al., 2011). 261
SO4 •- + SO4 •- → S2O8 2- (11) 262
SO4 •-+ S2O8 2- → SO4 2- + S2O8 •- (12) 263 3.3. Identification of the reactive free radical species for 1,4-dioxane degradation 264 within the persulfate-nFe3O4/biochar system 265 3.3.1. EPR studies 266 In order to verify the free radical species within the nFe3O4/biochar-persulfate 267 system, EPR spectroscopy combined with DMPO as the spin trapping agent was used 268 to determine the free radical species during the process of the 1,4-dioxane degradation 269 and results were presented in Fig. 3. After five minutes reaction of DMPO and 270 nFe3O4/biochar-persulfate, signals of DMPO-SO4 (with six lines of 1:1:1:1:1:1 and 271 the hyperfine splitting of αN = 13.2, αH = 9.6, αH = 1.48, αH = 0.78) and DMPO-OH 272 (with four lines of 1:2:2:1 and the hyperfine splitting of αN = αH = 14.9) were detected 273 in agreement with the previous studies (Furman et al., 2010; Duan et al., 2015). In 274 addition, the signal of DMPO-OH was found in the solution without the 275 nFe3O4/biochar suggesting the formation of •OH. This was attributable to the 276
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
14
persulfate decomposition at an ambient temperature generated SO4 •-, and SO4 •- react 277 with H2O through equation (7) (Zhu et al., 2014). However, the intensity signals of 278 DMPO-SO4 and DMPO-OH in the solution with an activator being added were 279 apparently higher than that in absence of the activator, implying that the 280 nFe3O4/biochar could activate persulfate to generate free radicals. More intensive 281 signals of DMPO-OH adducts than DMPO-SO4 resulted from the fast transformation 282 of DMPO-SO4 to DMPO-OH through nucleophilic substitution (Timmins et al., 1999; 283 Zhang et al., 2016). 284 3.3.2. Free radical quenching experiment 285 To further identify the predominant free radical species within nFe3O4/biochar- 286 persulfate system under different pH values, free radical quenching experiments were 287 performed. Ethanol and tert-butyl alcohol were selected as the free radical probes in 288 this study because of their significantly different reaction rate constants with SO4 •- and 289 •OH. As shown in Table 1, when the initial pH was 3.0, the degradation efficiencies of 290 1,4-dioxane declined from 96.7% in case of the blank test (without any adding of 291 alcohols) to 17.6% and 67.2%, respectively, by adding 5.0 mM EtOH and TBA. 292 Similarly, when the initial pH was 7.0, the degradation efficiency was decreased from 293 94.5% to 24.1% and 68.7% respectively by adding 5.0 mM EtOH and TBA. The data 294 obtained from the experiment indicated that the dominant active free radical was SO4 •- 295 when pH value was below 7.0. However, when the initial pH was 9.0, the degradation 296 efficiency decreased from 85.0% to 20.4% and 41.0% respectively by adding 5.0 mM 297 EtOH and TBA. The data obtained here manifested that more •OH was produced with 298
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
15
the increasing pH (equation (8)). 299 3.4. Activation mechanism of persulfate in the presence of nFe3O4/biochar 300 In order to understand the roles of Fe(II) and Fe(III) played in the persulfate 301 activation, the XPS spectra of nFe3O4/biochar were examined. The narrow scan XPS 302 spectrum of Fe(2p) of the nFe3O4/biochar (before and after reaction ) were shown in 303 Fig. 4a and 4b. The peaks at 710.0 eV and 711.6 eV, 713.0 eV, 714.3 eV and 724.6 eV 304 correspond to Fe(II) and Fe(III), suggesting that the Fe(II) and Fe(III) states coexisted 305 in the nFe3O4/biochar (Grosvenor et al., 2004; Wilson and Langell, 2014; Zubir et al., 306 2014). Based on deconvolution of Fe(2p) envelope and peak area, the percentage of 307 Fe(II) and Fe(III) were 49% and 51% respectively in fresh nFe3O4/biochar. After the 308 1,4-dioxane degradation for several hours, the percentage of Fe(III) was increased to 309 100%, implying that electrons had transferred from Fe(II) to persulfate on the surface 310 of nFe3O4/biochar and activated persulfate to generate SO4 •-. 311 As shown in Fig. 4c and 4d, the C(1s) spectra could be deconvoluted into four 312 peaks assigned to C=C, C-C, C-H (284.4 eV and 285.1 eV.), C-OH (286.1 eV) and 313 COOH (288.9 eV) before the reaction and five peaks assigned to C=C (C-C, C-H), 314 C-OH, C=O (288.2 eV) and COOH after the reaction (Qian and Chen., 2013; Zubir et 315 al., 2014; Yan et al., 2016). The percentages of COOH and C-OH decreased from 9.4% 316 to 4.3% and 15.4% to 14.7% respectively after the reaction. Indicating that, by 317 releasing proton, C-OH and COOH transformed into CO• and COO• and activated 318 persulfate to generate sulfate free radicals (Niu et al., 2011; Yan et al., 2016). The 319 peak of C=O was appeared after the reaction due to the oxidation of C=C by the 320
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
16
equations (13), (14) and (15) (Milas et al., 2002). In addition, the C=O group could 321 activate persulfate for the generation of free radicals (Duan et al., 2015). 322
SO4 •- + H2O → HSO4 - + •OH (13) 323 2•OH + RCH=CHR → HO-HC(R)CH(R)-OH (14) 324 HO-CRH-CRH-OH → R-HCO-R + H2O (15) 325 Based on the above results and analysis, the underlying mechanism of 326 nFe3O4/biochar for 1,4-dioxane degradation was proposed in Fig. 5. There are three 327 main pathways for the persulfate activation: (a) the reactive sites of nFe3O4 dispersed 328 onto the surface of biochar activate persulfate to generate sulfate free radicals through 329 the transfer of an electron from Fe(II) to persulfate; (b) the functional groups within 330 biochar such as -COOH and C-OH could activate persulfate and (c) the carbon-carbon 331 double bond would be transformed into glycol through addition reaction with •OH 332 generated from the reaction between SO4 •- and water molecule. The dihydric alcohol 333 would generate ketonic or quinonic groups correspondingly via Pinacol 334 rearrangement, which can activate persulfate in further steps. 335
336 4. Conclusions 337 In this study, nFe3O4/biochar was successfully synthesized and characterized. 338 The factors controlled the degradation of 1,4-dioxane by nFe3O4/biochar activating 339 persulfate were explored. The optimized composite mass ratio between nano 340 magnetite and biochar was determined to be 1:1 and the pyrolysis temperature of 341 biochar was 400 oC based on the experimental results. The underlying mechanism of 342
H+
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
17
nFe3O4/biochar activating persulfate was studied by EPR, free radical quenching 343 experiment and XPS analysis. It was revealed that the predominant free radicals were 344 SO4 •- under acidic and neutral solutions. However, the predominant free radicals were 345 •OH and SO4 •- under alkaline solutions. In addition, Fe(II) and oxygenated functional 346 groups of biochar such as carboxyl could be also accounted for the activating 347 persulfate. 348

Highlights
1. Nano magnetite biochar composite (nFe3O4/biochar) was synthesized and
characterized as a persulfate activator.
2. 1,4-dioxane was effectively removed within the persulfate-nFe3O4/biochar system
under a wide range of pH from 3.0-9.0.
3. Controlling factors of 1,4-dioxane degradation were evaluated. 4. The possible mechanism of persulfate activation by nFe3O4/biochar was
elucidated.

referenceMentions.context: Introduction 35 1,4-dioxane is classified as a potential B2 carcinogen by the Environmental 36 Protection Agency of the United States (Eberle et al., 2016) and has been frequently 37 detected in groundwater and surface waters (Barndõk et al.
It was mainly used as a stabilizing agent for chlorinated hydrocarbons and 40 existed as a by-product in many cosmetics (Abe, 1999; Sekar and Dichristina, 2014).
It was mainly used as a stabilizing agent for chlorinated hydrocarbons and 40 existed as a by-product in many cosmetics (Abe, 1999; Sekar and Dichristina, 2014).
On account of its high efficiency for the removal 52 of 1,4-dioxane in soil and water, AOP based on persulfate has attracted much attention 53 in recent years (Sekar and Dichristina, 2014).
54 Transitional metals such as Fe, Co and Ag can activate persulfate to generate 55 SO4 •- (Teel et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2012) and Fe is one of the most effective reagents 56

Biochar possesses a variety of oxygen-containing 79 functional groups such as carboxyl, hydroxyl and carbonyl, which can activate 80 pesulfate to generate SO4 •- (Liang et al., 2009; Duan et al., 2015).
In addition, biochar 81 can be successfully employed to disperse and stabilize nanoparticles to enhance their 82 potential in environmental applications (Yan et al., 2014; Han et al., 2015).
As shown above, the increase of 179 pyrolysis temperature leads to the loss of oxygen functional groups and the growth of 180 aromatic structures (Tilly, 2003).

Comparing with P300, P400, P500 and P700, the 181 bending for vibrations of Fe-O (585 cm) and Fe-O (445 cm) appeared in 182 nFe3O4/biochar (Ahmad et al., 2009), indicating of nFe3O4 being successfully loaded 183 onto biochar.

4 Effects of persulfate concentration on 1,4-dioxane degradation 248 The concentration of persulfate is another important factor affecting the 249 1,4-dioxane removal efficiency (Long et al., 2014; Eberle et al., 2016).

At high persulfate concentrations, the SO4 •257 generated from nFe3O4/biochar-persulfate system increased and excessive persulfate 258 reacts with SO4 •- to form S2O8 (equation (11) and (12)) itself, resulting in the decrease 259 in 1,4-dioxane degradation (Liang et al., 2004a; Yu et al., 2004; Liang and Lee, 2008; 260 Yan et al., 2011).
